did.abstract: Collection includes Reading Center client files, student papers, reports, newsletters, pamphlets, a time capsule, and a video tape, and range in date from 1930 to 1992. Materials were put on exhibit in the Fall of 2004 in the Gelman Library to celebrate the Centenary of the School.

prefercite.head: Preferred citation
prefercite.p: Graduate School of Education and Human Development records, University Archives, Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Series 1 is closed to research for 75 years from date of record creation.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Materials acquired through transfers from Graduate School of Education and Human Development.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

bioghist.head: Historical or Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Clearly identified professional courses for teachers at The George Washington University were first offered in 1904-05, and the Division of Education, under the Columbian College, was established in 1907. In 1909 this division became the Teachers College, and in 1928 the School of Education.

By this time its faculty were staffing departments of education, educational psychology and home economics. In 1932, a year before it began its doctoral programs, the School accepted the responsibility for providing required physical education to all GW undergraduates, until the '60s when these requirements were dropped.

In 1977 the name was again changed to the School of Education and Human Development. The School is a unit within the University structure having jurisdiction over professional teacher education programs, as well as other professional programs in education and human development. Up until this time the School also oversaw the Reading Center.

In 1987 the School was organized into four departments: Department of Teacher Preparation and Special Education; the Department of Human Kinetics and Tourism; the Department of Educational Leadership, and the Department of Human Services. Each is headed by a department chair.

Since 1994 the School has been known as The Graduate School of Education and Human Development, when it transitioned from a comprehensive undergraduate/graduate entity to one focusing exclusively on graduate education. In 2004 the School celebrated its Centenary. The Dean of the School reports to the Executive Vice President for Academic Affairs.
N.B. This history note was written in 2005

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Materials in this collection include Reading Center client files, student papers, reports, newsletters, pamphlets, a time capsule, and a video tape, and range in date from 1930 to 2011. Materials were put on exhibit in the Fall of 2004 in the Gelman Library to celebrate the Centenary of the School. They were transferred to the University Archives by the Dean of the Graduate School of Education and Human Development and faculty members. Note: Not all series are processed. Ask staff for assistance.

arrangement.head: Collection Organization
arrangement.p: Organized into nine series: Reading Center files; Student papers; Time capsule; Newsletter and pamphlets; Video tape; Adult education study; Report; Papers; and Centers and departmental files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of Reading Center client files [Reading Center closed in 1992]. They range in date from c.1970-c.1990. The material was transferred to University Archives in 1992.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of student papers - "The Practical Arithmetic for Seventh Grade" (1934), "Internal School Finances" (1953), "Inquiries into Selected Concepts Relating to Musicality in Children" (1964), and "Curriculum Materials, Educ. 207: Your Rights and Reponsibilities as an American Citizen"(1976). They range in date from 1934-76. The material was added to the University Archives collections from a backlog in 2003.

did.unittitle: Student papers -- "The Practical Arithmetic for Seventh Grade" (1934), "Internal School Finances" (1953), "Inquiries into Selected Concepts Relating to Musicality in Children" (1964), and "Curriculum Materials, Educ. 207: Your Rights and Responsibilities as an American Citizen" (1976)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of a time capsule of students ambitions after graduation, and is dated from 1996. The material was transferred to University Archives in 1996.

did.unittitle: Time capsule of students' ambitions after graduation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of the newsletter "New Directions" and GSEHD program pamphlets. The material ranges in date from 1993 to 2011.

did.unittitle: "Perspectives on Educational Certificate Programs", Margaret E. Holt and George J. Copos, eds.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of an "Adult Education Study" by James Fox, Ralph Ruffner, James Hall for the GW School of Education. It dates from 1949 and was donated to the University Archives by John Boswell in 2000.

did.unittitle: "Adult Education Study" by James Fox, Ralph Ruffner, James Hall (GW School of Education)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of a videotape interview conducted by professor John Boswell, School of Education, with president Lloyd Elliott, on GW's role as an educational institution. It is dated from 1988 and was donated to the University Archives by John Boswell in 2001.

did.unittitle: Videotape interview conducted by Professor John Boswell, School of Education, with President Lloyd Elliott on GW's role as an educational institution

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of a report to the National Council for Accreditation of Teacher Education, March 4-6, 1974 and March 26-28, 1984 (2 volumes), and the 2008-2009 Annual Report for the Granduate School of Education and Human Development.

did.unittitle: Report to National Council for Accreditation of Teacher Education
Report to the National Council for Accreditation of Teacher Education, March 4-6, 1974 and March 26-28, 1984 (2 volumes)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of studies and papers on various aspects of education and training. The materials range in date from 1970-92. The material was transferred to University Archives in 1995.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains memorandums, brochures, invitations, flyers, newsletters, posters, a bibliography, press releases, handbooks, programs, forms, and reports. They range in date from 1930 to 1991. This series consists of material relating to the Alumni Association for the Graduate School of Education and Human Development; the Reading Center; the Regional Rehabilitation Research Institution on Attitudinal, Legal and Leisure Barriers; rehabilitation counselor education; the Rehabilitation Research and Training Center; special education for early childhood; the graduate program in physical education for the handicapped; the Special Education Instructional Materials Center (SEIMC); the Department of Special Education; the complementary teacher program; degree descriptions; "Together... the Special Education/Early Child Program The George Washington University: a three year report"; the Physical Education Department; "Rx: Exchange: Therapeutic Recreation & Adaptive Physical Education; conferences; the Charles E. Smith Center; workshops; the Department of Physical Education , Health, and Recreation; the Women's Recreation Association, home economics, dietetics for navy nurses.
